Aux termes de 1'article 4 du Reglement de 1'Assemblee, 1'ordre du jour de chaque session annuelle doit comprendre :a) un rapport sur Toeuvre du Conseil accomplie depuis la dernieresession de 1'Assemblee ;b) un rapport du Secretaire general sur le travail du Secretariat et surles mesures prises pour executer les decisions de 1'Assemblee.Une partie considerable des travaux du Conseil, au cours de ces derniers mois, a ete consacree aux mesures necessaires pour executer les resolutions et les recommandations de la premiere Assemblee. On a done juge opportun, pour eviter les repetitions, de reunir les deux rapports mentionnes a 1'article 4 du Reglement.Le chapitre Ier du rapport presente un apercu general des travaux dont le Conseil a pris 1'initiative; ce chapitre Ier constitue, avec les parties du chapitre II qui traitent des mesures prises par le Conseil, le premier des deux rapports prevus par le Reglement de 1'Assemblee.'Le chapitre II rend compte des mesures prises pour executer les decisions de 1'Assemblee ; il constitue done, avec le chapitre III, le deuxieme rapport prevu par le Reglement. LEAGUE OF nations report ON THE WORK OF THE COUNCIL AND ON THE MEASURES TAKEN TO EXECUTE THE DECISIONS OF THE FIRSTASSEMBLY.Note. - According to Article 4 of the Rules of Procedure of the Assembly, the agenda of a general session shall include :(a) A report upon the work of the Council since the last session.(Z*) A report by the Secretary-General upon the work of the Secretariat and upon the measures taken to execute the decisions of the Assembly.A considerable part of the work of the Council during the last months has consisted in the steps which it has taken to carry out the resolutions and recom-mendations of the first Assembly. It has therefore been found convenient to combine the two reports described in Article 4 of the Rules of Procedure in order to avoid presenting the same material twice over.Chapter I of the report is an account of the general work of the Council undertaken on its own initiative, and, together with the relevant portions of Chapter II, may be regarded as the first of the two reports required by the Rules of Procedure.Chapter II of the report is an account of the measures taken to execute the decisions of the Assembly and may be regarded, with Chapter III, as the second of the two reports required by the Rules of Procedure.s. d. GHAPITRE PREMIERAPERCU GENERAL DES TRAVAUXDU GONSEIL CHAPTER ONETHE GENERAL WORK OF THECOUNCIL A. MESURES ADMINISTRATIVES PRISES PAR LE CONSEIL EN VERTU DES TRAITES DE PAIX.I. TERRITOIRE DE LA SARRE.La Commission de Gouvernement.Conformement aux stipulations du Traite de Versailles, le Bassin de la Sarre est gouverne par une Commission de cinq membres nommes par le Conseil. Le mandat de quatre de ces membres nommes pour une annee expirant le 13 fevrier 1921, le Conseil, lors de sa douzieme session a Parie, a renouvele ce mandat pour une autre annee. Ces membres sont :M. LAMBERT........ . Beige.Comte de MOLTKE-HUITFELD . Danois.M.V. RAULT .......... Francais.M. R. D. WAUGH........ Canadien.M. Rault a ete de nouveau nomme President. Le cinquieme membre, M. Hector (Sarrois), ayant ete nomme le 20 septembre 1920 pour succeder au premier membre sarrois de la Commission, demissionnaire, reste en fonctions jusqu'au 20 septembre 1921.Protestations du Gouvernement Allemand.Depuis la premiere session de 1'Assemblee, le Conseil a examine trois questions relatives au Bassin de la Sarre, soulevees par le Gouvernement allemand. Ce dernier protestait contre certains faits ou certaines mesures prises dans le Bassin de la Sarre et reclamait 1'intervention de la Societe des Nations.Le Gouvernement allemand protestait contre :1. la presence des troupes francaises et 1'exercice de la juridiction militaire francaise sur le territoire de la Sarre ;2. 1'expulsion d'habitants de la Sarre ;3. 1'introduction de 1'emploi de la monnaie francaise dans les services de chemins de fer, postes, telegraphes et telephones.Apres avoir etudie les notes allemandes sur ces differents points, ainsi que les observations et les explications presentees par le President de la Commission de gouvernement, le Conseil a adopte trois rapports. Ces rapports, et la correspon-dance relative a ces questions, ont ete communiques a tous les Membres de la Societe des Nations a titre d'information.M. Rault assistait a la seance du Conseil consacree a ces questions. Le'Conseil lui exprima son approbation generale pour son administration.i0 Presence de troupes francaises et exercice de la juridiction militaire frangaise dans la Sarre.Le Gouvernement allemand protestait non seulement contre la presence de troupes francaises et contre l'exercice de la juridiction militaire dans le territoire de la Sarre, mais aussi contre le maintien d'une force speciale de gendarmerie francaise, qui, de 1'avis du Gouvernement allemand, servait en quelque sorte de police politique. II protestait egalement contre 1'application de la loi francaise aux habitants de la Sarre, par des conseils de guerre, jugeant au nom du peuple francais et non pas au nom de la Commission de gouvernement. A. THE ADMINISTRATIVE WORK OF THE COUNCIL ARISING OUT OF THE PEACE TREATIES.I. THE TERRITORY OF THE SAAR.The Governing Commission.In accordance with the provisions of the Treaty, of Versailles, the Saar Basin has been governed by a Commission of five, appointed by the Council. The term of office of four of the five members who were appointed for the first year of the Commission^ work expired on February 13th, 1921, and the Council during its 12th session in Paris reappointed these members for another yearM. LAMBERT ......... Belgian.Count de MOLTKE-HUITFELDT Dane.M. V. RAULT........ . French.Mr. R. D. WAUGH ...... Canadian.M. Rault was again appointed Chairman. M. Hector (Sarrois), the fifth member of the Commission, was appointed on September 20th, 1920, as successor to the original Saar member of the Commission, resigned. He therefore holds office until September 20th, 1921.Protests of the German Government.Since the first session of the Assembly, the Council has considered three questions concerning the Saar Basin raised by the German Government, which has protested against certain conditions or certain measures taken in the Saar Basin, and requested action by the League of Nations.The three questions were :(1) The presence of French troops and the application of French military law in the Saar ;(2) The expulsion of inhabitants from the Saar ;(3) The introduction of French money in the railway, postal, telegraph and telephone services.After examination of the German notes on these subjects and the observa-tions and statements of the Chairman of the Governing Commission, the Council adopted three reports which, together with the correspondence on these questions, have been communicated to ah the Members of the League of Nations for their informationM. Rault was present during the discussion of these questions by the Council, which expressed general approval of his administration.(1) The Presence of French Troops and the Application of French Military Law in the Saar.The German Government protested not only against the presence of French troops in the Saar and the exercise of military jurisdiction over the inhabitants, but also against the maintenance of a special French gendarmerie which was used, it was alleged, as a kind of special political police, and against the application to Saar inhabitants by French courts-martial of French law on behalf of the French nation and not of the Governing Commission. 'Le Gouvernement allemand invoquait le paragraphe 30 de 1'annexe au Traite de Versailles, relative au Bassin de la Sarre, pour alleguer qu'on ne devait conserver sur le territoire qu'une gendarmerie locale en vue du maintien de 1'ordre. Etant donne que cette gendarmerie avait ete constituee par decret en juillet 1920, la decision prise par le Conseil le 13fevrier 1920, autorisant la Commission degou-vernement a requerir 1'aide de certaines troupes en attendant la constitution d'une force de gendarmerie, ne pouvait plus, de 1'avis du Gouvernement alle-mand, justifier le maintien de ces troupes. Dans tous les cas, selon le Gouverne-ment allemand, les habitants des territoires ne pouvaient etre juges que confor-mement aux lois prevues par le Traite et par les tribunaux institues a cet effet.En consequence, 1'Allemagne reclamait le retrait des troupes francaises, F abolition de la juridiction des conseils de guerre et Fannulation des jugements prononces par ces derniers contre les habitants.La Commission de gouvernement a faitressortir qu'aux termes du paragraphe 30, il lui incombait de prendre toutes les mesures necessaires pour proteger les habitants et les proprietes ; que les troupes en question ne constituaient pas une armee d'occupation, mais une garnison, et que leur chef etait tenu d'obeir a tous les ordres du President de la Commission ; que, d'autre part, une gendarmerie locale possederait tous les defauts inherents a une police recrutee sur place et que 1'entretien d'une force de police locale suffisante constituerait une lourde charge pour les ressources financieres du territoire. La Commission a declare egalement que, suivant la procedure adoptee deja depuis quelques mois, les conseils de guerre ne jugeraient plus que les cas universellement reconnus comme relevant du droit international et qu'ils n'exerceraient aucune juridiction sur les habitants.Le rapport sur cette question adopte par le Conseil concluait, apres avoir examine la situation, qu'il n'y avait pas lieu de modifier Fopinion du Conseil deja exprimee le 13 fevrier 1920 : etant donne qu'il incombe a la Commission de proteger les personnes et la propriete, elle a egalement le droit de demander le maintien ou le renvoi de la totalite ou d'une partie des troupes appelees a main-tenir 1'ordre et ce, en cas d'urgence, jusqu'a l'etablissement d'une force de gendar-merie sarroise. Le rapport declarait en outre que 1'obligation de maintenir 1'ordre etait de la plus grande importance et comportait le droit d'utiliser, en cas de besoin, toutes forces qui pourraient Stre mises a la disposition de la Commission. La Corn-mission seule etait juge du degrede necessite. D'autre part, la Commission etait evidemment responsable vis-a-vis de la Societe des Nations de la maniere dont elle pourrait exercer ce droit. Le Conseil n'envisageait pas le maintien d'une garhison etrangere comme une des conditions permanentes de 1'organisation de la Sarre, et decidait qu'il y aurait lieu de se passer de troupes etrangeres des que lagendar-merie locale serait suffisamment organisee.Quant a 1'exercice de la juridiction militaire, le Conseil etait d'avis qu'en temps normal la justice ne pouvait etre rendue qu'au nom de la Commission de gouvernement, conformement a la legislation en vigueur dans la Sarre en novem-bre 1918 (sous reserve de toutes modifications qui y seraient apportees par la Commission apres avoir consulte les representants elus des habitants) et unique-ment par les tribunaux designes dans le Traite. Le Conseil reconnaissait la situa-tion speciale dans laquelle se trouvait la Commission de gouvernement ; il etait d'avis qu'on pouvait difficilement lui refuser le droit de transferer, si elle le jugeait necessaire, ce droit de juridiction a des conseils de guerre ; neanmoins, il estimait que c'etaient la des circonstances speciales. qui ne pouvaient guere se produire a 1'avenir, apres la creation de la Cour supreme du Bassin de la Sarre.Les conclusions de ce rapport ont ete communiquees a la Commission de gou-vernement a titre de directives, avec priere de vouloir bien fournir dans ses rapports periodiques des renseignements detailles sur les progres de 1'organisation de la gendarmerie locale et sur la possibilite de reduire 1'effectif de la garnison francaise. Un exemplaire de ce rapport a ete egalement adresse au Gouvernement allemand.20 Expulsion habitants de la Sarre.Par lettre au Secretaire general, en date du 31 mars 1921, le Gouvernement allemand a proteste contre les expulsions k en masse v d'habitants du Bassin de la Sarre, expulsions, declarait-il, ordonnees par les autorites militaires francaises au cours d'une greve de fonctionnaires en aout 1920, apres la proclamation de 1'etat de siege par la Commission de gouvernement. ii protestait egalement' The German Government claimed that under paragraph 30 of the Saar Annex to the Treaty of Versailles, no forces should be maintained in the Saar for the preservation of order except the local gendarmerie ; that, as this gendar-merie had been constituted by decree in July, 1920, the decision of the Council on February 13th, 1920, that the Governing Commission might have the assistance of certain troops in the Saar, pending the establishment of a gendarmerie of the Saar, could no longer justify their retention ; and that in any case jurisdiction could not be exercised over the inhabitants except in accordance with the laws and by the tribunals provided for in the Treaty.Germany therefore asked that the French troops should be removed, that the jurisdiction of the courts-martial should be abolished, and that the sentences pronounced by them on the inhabitants should be annulled.The Governing Commission pointed out that under paragraph 30 it was obliged to provide in all cases for the protection of ' persons and property ; that the troops were not a force of occupation, but garrison troops, and that their commander must comply with all requests made by the Chairman of the Commission ; that a local gendarmerie would possess the defects inherent in police obtained by local recruiting ; and that the maintenance of a sufficiently large local force would be a crushing charge upon the financial resources of the Terri-tory. It also stated that, in accordance with the practice which had been adopted for some months, the courts-martial " would deal only with cases covered by the regulations generally recognised in international law", and that they had no jurisdiction over the inhabitants.The report on this question adopted by the Council reviewed the situation and concluded that there was no reason to modify the attitude of the Council as expressed on February 13th, 1920, when it was held that by reason of theCom-mission's duty " to protect persons and property, it would have the power to demand the maintenance or return of all or a part of the troops called up to preserve order, if necessary till the establishment of a Saar gendarmerie." It was further stated in the report that the duty of maintaining order was paramount and carried with it the right to make use, in cases of necessity, of any force which could be placed at the disposal of the Commission and that the Commission must be the judge of the degree of necessity. It was laid down, on the other hand, that the Commission was, of course, responsible to the League of Nations for the manner in which it exercised this discretion and that the Council did not contem-plate the maintenance of a foreign garrison as a permanent feature of the organi-sation of the Saar, but adopted the policy of dispensing with the support of foreign troops as soon as the development of the local gendarmerie permittedWith regard to the exercise of military jurisdiction, the Council held the view that justice could only in normal circumstances be exercised in the name of the Governing Commission, in accordance with the law in force there on November 11th, 1918, subject to any modifications of the law made by the Corn-mission after consulting the elected representatives of the inhabitants, and only by the courts named in the Treaty. Although the Council recognised the emer-gency in which the Governing Commission had found itself, and considered that the Commission could hardly be denied the right of giving jurisdiction, so far as it considered it necessary, to courts-martial, it took the view that such exceptional circumstances were not likely to arise in the future after the establishment of the Supreme Court of the Saar Basin.The conclusions of the report were communicated to the Governing Commission for its guidance, with the request that detailed information as to the development of the local gendarmerie and as to the prospects of reducing the French troops should be inserted in its periodical reports. A copy of the report was also sent to the German Government.(2) The Expulsion of Inhabitants from the SaarThe German Government, in a letter to the Secretary-General of March 31st, 1921, protested against the expulsions " en masse " of inhabitants of the Saar Basin which, it stated, had been effected by French military authority during a strike of officials in August, 1920, after the proclamation of a state of siege by the Governing Commission. It also protested against the continued exclusion contre le fait que le retour d'un grand riombre de ces expulses restait encore interdit, malgre la levee de 1'etat de siege.Le Gouvernement allemand a soutenu que ces expulsions etaient contraires au Traite de Versailles, a la loi relative a la liberte de deplacement et de residence, en vigueur dans la Sarre, et au devoir de proteger la population qui incombait a la Commission. II a declare, en outre, que ces expulsions s'efiectuaient souvent avec une grande rigueur et que des personnes qui n'etaient pour rien dans la greve des fonctionnaires en avaient ete victimes.Dans des rapports anterieurs, le President de la Commission de gouverne-ment avait declare que, au moment de la greve, il avait donne au general francais, commandant les troupes, pleins pouvoirs pour assurer 1'ordre et que ce dernier avait juge necessaire d'ordonner 1'expulsion d'une centaine environ de panger-manistes notoires, dont la plupart n'etaient pas originaires du territoire de la Sarre.Le Conseil a estime a nouveau que la Commission devait avoir tous les pouvoirs necessaires dans le cas d'evenements extraordinaires, mais il a juge que la situa-tion serait differente apres le retour aux conditions normales. II a done recommande a la Commission de proceder a une nouvelle enquete sur tous les ordres d'expul-sion encore en vigueur, afin de les reduire au minimum ; il a demande egalement que, pour tous les cas examines, un rapport fut bientdt adresse au Conseil. Copie du rapport adopte a ete adressee au Gouvernement allemand.30 Introduction de Vemploi de la monnaie francaise dans les services des chemins de fer, posies, telegraphes et telephones.Le Gouvernement allemand a declare que le decret de la Commission de Gouvernement, en date du 16 mars 1921, substituant le franc au mark comme monnaie legale pour les salaires et les tarifs en vigueur dans les services postaux, telephoniques et telegraphiques de la Sarre, etait contraire au g 32 de 1'annexe du Traite de Versailles relatif a la Sarre. Cette annexe stipulait qu'aucune res-restriction ne serait apportee a la circulation de la monnaie francaise dans le terri-toire et particulierement a 1'usage de la monnaie francaise par les mines appar-tenant a 1'Etat francais. L'AUemagne soutenait que ce paragraphe impliquait que le mark etait la seule monnaie legale du territoire et que la circulation du franc etait simplement toleree par le Traite. Le President de la Commission de gouvernement, d'autre part, affirmait que, outre les droits- conferes aux mines appartenant a 1'Etat francais, le g 32 autorisait la Commission de gouvernement a faire du franc la monnaie legale, si elle le jugeait convenable ; il ajoutait que le Traite ne prevoyait pas le maintien du mark comme seule monnaie legale du territoire ; que, d'apres le g 19, la Commission de gouvernement avait pleins pouvoirs pour l'administration et la bonne marche des services publics et que, d'apres 1'article 33, la Commission de gouvernement elle-meme avait la com-competence necessaire pour interpreter ces stipulations. De plus, la Commission de gouvernement faisait remarquer que ce decret avait ete adopte en raison de la valeur plus stable du franc et parce que les operations financieres importantes de ces services etaient faites en cette monnaie.Le Conseil, apres avoir examine en detail la situation au point de vue juri-dique et pratique, a estime que le Traite ne prevoyait pas que le mark fut conserve comme seule monnaie legale dans le territoire et que, en promulguant ce decret, la Commission n'avait pas excede les pouvoirs qu'elle tenait des articles 19 et 33, bien que la question de 1'application de 1'article 23, stipulant que les modifica-tions apportees aux lois du territoire doivent etre precedees d'une consulta-tion des representants des habitants, ne soit pas en 1'espece d'une clarte absolue. Le rapport se termine par une resolution declarant que le decret du 16 mars ne donne lieu a aucune observation de la part du Conseil. Cette resolution a ete communiquee au Gouvernement allemand.Expeditions par voies ferrees a destination ou en provenance du territoire de la Sarre.Cette question, qui a ete soulevee par la Commission de gouvernement, est inscrite a 1'ordre du jour de la session de septembre du Conseil. La Commission : de gouvernement declare que la Sarre n'a pu adherer a la Convention internatio- from the Territory, after the removal of the state of siege, of many of the persons who had been expelled.The German Government contended that these expulsions were contrary to the Treaty of Versailles, to the law concerning liberty of movement and resi-dence in force in the Saar, and to the Commission^ duty of protecting the popu-lation. It stated, moreover, that the expulsions were frequently carried out with great severity, and against- persons in no way connected with the strike of officials.In previous reports, the Chairman of the Governing Commission had explained that, at the time of the strike, he had given the French general in command of the troops complete freedom to ensure order, and that the latter had considered it necessary to decree the expulsion of about one hundred notorious Pan-Germans, mostly foreign to the Territory.The Council again took the view that the Commission must have all neces-sary power in cases of emergency, but it held that the position would be diffe-rent after a return to normal conditions. It therefore recommended that the Commission should institute a new enquiryintoseach sentence of expulsion still in force, in order to reduce them to a minimum, and it asked that reports should in each case be made to the Council at an early opportunity. A copy of the report adopted was sent to the German Government.(3) The Introduction of French Money in the Railway, Postal, Telegraph and Telephone Services.The German Government protested that the Governing Commission^ decree of March 16th, 1921, by which the franc was substituted for the mark as the cur-rency to be used for salaries and rates in the postal, telephone and telegraph services of the Saar, was contrary to paragraph 32 of the Saar Annex to the Treaty of Versailles, which provided that no restriction should be imposed on the cir-speculation of French money in the Territory, and especially on the use of French money by the French State Mines. Germany contended that this paragraph implied that the mark was the sole legal currency of the Territory, and that the circulation of the franc was merely legally tolerated. The Chairman of the Governing Commission argued, on the other hand, that in addition to the rights which were given to the French State Mines, paragraph 32 authorised the Gover-ning Commission to make the franc legal tender if it thought fit to do so, that the Treaty did not provide for the retention of the mark as the sole legal currency in the Territory, that under paragraph 19 the Governing Commission had full power to administer and operate the public services, and that by Article 33 the Governing Commission itself had the authority to interpret these provisions. THE FREE CITY OF DANZIG.During the first session of the Assembly, the Councilin a report and resolu-tion adopted on November 17th, 1920, laid clown the general lines of the policy to be pursued in discharging those duties with regard to the Free City of Danzig which were entrusted to the League of Nations by the Treaty of Ver-sailles. After a careful consideration of the specific provisions of the Treaty and the international position of the Free City, the Council decided : (a) That Danzig should be placed under the protection of the League of Nations from the time of its establishment (November 15th, 1920) ; and that Poland appeared particularly fitted to be, if the circumstances required it, entrusted by the League of Nations with the duty of ensuring the defence of the Free City.(b) That the Constitution should be placed under the guarantee of the League of Nations, also from November 15th, 1920, but that Danzig should be requested to make certain specified changes in the text of that document.(c) That no modification contrary to the statute of the Free City should be introduced, without the previous assent of the League, into the Polish-Danzig Convention of November 9th, 1920, which was noted, in draft form, by the Council.(d) That the High Commissioner of the League of Nations in Danzig, one of whose principal duties would be to settle differences arising between Poland and Danzig under the Convention of November 9 th, should be appointed for three years, and that the expenses of the post should be divided between Poland and Danzig.The subsequent action of the Council on Danzig questions has been largely in the nature of a practical application, or execution, of the decisions taken at the November session.Seven questions relating to Danzig were discussed at the 12th session of the Council (February-March, 1921), and fourteen questions at the 13th session (June, 1921). During the 13th session, General Haking, the High Commis-sioner, President Sahm of the Danzig Senate, and M. Askenazy, the Polish Delegate, were present during the discussion of Danzig questions by the Council. THE AALAND ISLANDS.It was recorded in the report on the work of the Council presented to the first Assembly that on September 20th, 1920, the Council had decided to appoint a Commission of Rapporteurs for the Aaland Islands "charged with the duty of furnishing the Council, in the shortest time required for necessary consultations and having regard to the legitimate interests of all parties concerned, with a report which would enable it to frame a final or provisional settlement of the question and to establish conditions favourable to the maintenance of peace in that part of the world."This Commission was duly appointed, and during November and December, 1920, it pursued its investigations at Stockholm and Helsingfors and in the Aaland Archipelago. The members of the Commission were Baron Beyens, M. Felix Calonder and M. Abram J. Elkus. The Commission drafted its report in February and the report was presented to the Council during its 13th Session, held in Geneva. .The Report of the Commission of Rapporteurs.The Commission recommended that the Aaland Islands should remain under the sovereignty of Finland subject to guarantees obtained from the Fin-nish Government for the protection of the Swedish language and culture of the islanders.The Commission concluded that Finland had been an autonomous State continuously" for over one hundred years and that the Aaland Archipelago formed part of this autonomous State. It expressed the opinion that, whereas Finland, as an autonomous State of long-standing and as a people with a clearly defined territory and well-developed national life, might reasonably be allowed to de-termine her separation from Russia, no such right of. self-determination could be claimed by the islanders, who constituted only a small fraction of the Finnish nation. The Commission held that it would be unwise to sanction the separation of the islands from Finland as the result of a plebiscite, since " the separation of a minority from the State of which it forms a part and its incorporation in another State can only be considered as an altogether exceptional solution, a last resort when the State lacks either the will or the power to enact and apply just and effective guarantees. " The Commission pointed out that, unlike Fin-land, the Aaland Islands had been neither persecuted nor oppressed and that the Aaland population was merely threatened in its language and its racial sentiment by the fact that the Swedish-speaking population of Finland was a small minority.The Commission'recognised that the islanders by position and tradition were a group apart in Finland, quite distinct from the Finnish population and even from the Swedish-speaking population of the mainland. It sympathised with their ardent desire to preserve intact their language and culture, but considered that, as the Finnish State was ready to grant guarantees to the inhabitants and faithfully to observe its engagements with them, it would be inequitable from the point of view of history, geography, and politics to decide in favour of a separation.The Commission carefully defined the guarantees which it considered to be essential to complete the Law of Autonomy which had been voted by the Finnish Diet in 1920. It recommended that primary and technical schools of the pro-vinces of Aaland should give instruction only in Swedish and that the exclusion , of Finnish should be obligatory. The exclusive ownership and enjoyment of their property -should be reserved for the communes and their inhabitants, and, in order to provide against the possibility of Finnish companies acquiring land for the construction of building-yards and a consequent influx Of Finnish workmen, the right of pre-emption, at a price to be equitably fixed by a Commission - ltf -prix equitable fixe par une Commission nominee par le Conseil general cles lies cTAland, devait etre reserve aux habitants des lies chaque fois qu'une offre d'achat serait faite par une compagnie ou par une personne etrangere. La Com-mission recommandait egalement qu'on amendat un article de la loi actuelle d'autonomie, d'apres lequel tout etranger arrivant dans 1'ile pouvait obtenir immediatement droit de cite et qu'un sejour de cinq ans .au moins flit declare necessaire avant que le droit de cite put etre revendique par des etrangers.La Commission proposait, en outre, que le gouverneur des iles fut choisi sur une liste de trois candidats presentes par le Conseil general d'Aland. Elle pensait qu'au cas oil le Gouvernement finlandais refuserait d'accorder ces garan-ties essentielles, les habitants seraient en droit d'exiger un plebiscite. Le Conseil devait, a son avis, recommander au Gouvernement finlandais d'accorder ces garanties et lui declarer que dans ce cas la loi d'autonomie modifiee devait avoir un caractere international et recevoir la garautie de la Societe des Nations. La Commission proposait egalement, a ce sujet, de donner aux habitants des iles la possibilite de recourir au Conseil de la Societe des Nations et a la Cour per-permanente de Justice internationale en cas de difficulte ou de conflit.La Commission examinait egalement les mesures a prendre pour assurer la neutralisation militaire de 1'archipelago. Elle ne mettait pas en doute que la Con-vention de 1856 par laquelle la France, la Grande-Bretagne, la Russie convenaient qu'aucune fortification ne devait etre etablie dans 1'archipelago,. ne demeurat en vigueur et qu'elle n'instituat dans 1'interet de 1'Europe un statut international particulier pour les iles. The Commission also recommended that an Article in the present Law of Autonomy, under which strangers arriving in the islands were immediately accorded the franchise, should be amended, and that a sojourn of at least five years should be necessary for strangers before they might claim the same rights as natives.The Commission also suggested that the Governors of the Islands should be chosen from a list of three candidates presented by the General Council of Aaland. , The Commission considered that in the event of the Finnish Govern-ment refusing these, essential guarantees, a plebiscite might justly be claimed by the islanders. It suggested that the Council should recommend the adoption of the guarantees to the Finnish Government, and it represented that, in this event, the amended Law of Autonomy would assume an international character and might be placed under the protection of the League of Nations. The Commission regarded it as proved that the Convention of 1856, under which France, Great Britain, and Russia agreed that they would not fortify the Aaland Islands, was still in force and that it established in the interests of Europe a special international status for the Islands. The fact that during the late war the Islands were fortified contrary to the Convention indicated, however, in the view of the Commission, that more effective guarantees were necessary. The Commission noted that the Swedish and Finnish Governments had agreed that the Islands might most conveniently be neutralised by a Convention in which Sweden, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Great Britain, Italy and Poland should participate and that the Swedish Government had already drafted a Convention on the subject, which, in principle, appeared to be satisfactory. The Commission considered that this Convention should deal solely with disarmament and neutralisation and that it should con-elude by designating the boundaries of the Islands.The Decision of the Council.The report of the Commission was considered by the Council during its 13th session. During the discussions, the representatives of Sweden and of Finland sat as members of the Council in accordance with the provisions of Article 15 of the Covenant. They presented further statements in regard to the dispute and particularly in regard to the conclusions of the Commission of Rapporteurs.Representatives of the Islands being in Geneva, the Council questioned them regarding the conditions under which they lived. It appeared from this examination that the islanders suffered under no oppression, but that they genuinely feared that an encroachment might be made upon their Swedish lan-guage and culture owing to immigration from the mainland.As a result of these discussions, at the meeting of the Council on June 24th, a recommendation was made that the sovereignty of the Aaland Islands should belong to Finland. It was recognised that certain further guarantees for the protection of the islanders were necessary, together with the conclusion of an arrangement for the neutralisation of the Archipelago.This recommendation was adopted by the Council.The Swedish representative, who said that it was with a feeling of profound disappointment that the Swedish nation would learn of the decision of the Council, read a statement which concluded as follows : " Sweden is ready loyally to recognise that the decision of the Council has the force given to it by the Covenant. But Sweden will not "abandon the hope that the day will come when the idea of justice shall have so per-meated the conscience of the peoples, that the claims inspired by such noble motives and a national feeling as deep as that of the population of the Aaland Isles will be triumphantly vindicated. Pendant cette periode, la ligne de demarcation entre les forces polonaises et les forces lithuaniennes, suivait, du Niemen jusqu'a Dvinsk, une ligne sud-ouest-nord-ouest passant a 40 km; au nord-oues1, de Vilna.En juillet 1920, sous la pression des Bolcheviks, les Polonais evacuerent Vilna. DISPUTE BETWEEN POLAND AND LITHUANIA.Origin of, the Dispute.The intervention of the Council in the dispute between Poland and Lithua-nia was invoked by Prince Sapieha, the Polish Minister for Foreign Affairs, in September, 1920. The situation was complicated and dangerous. The frontier between Poland and Lithuania had not been defined. The Supreme Council had, on December 8th, 1919, delimited a frontier known as the " Curzon " line, to the west of which Poland was authorised to establish a regular administration. This decision, however, had never been communicated to Lithuania or recognised by her ; moreover, this decision expressly reserved the rights of Poland as regards the territory to the east of the Curzon line.The city and territory of Vilna had been delivered from the Bolshevists by the Poles in the spring of 1919 and administered by Poland up to July, 1920. During this period, the line of demarcation between the Polish and Lithuanian forces followed from the Niemen as far as Dvinsk a line south-west, north-east, passing 40 km. to the north-west of Vilna.In July, 1920, under the pressure of the Bolshevists, the Poles evacuated Vilna, while at the same time, by the Treaty of Moscow, signed on July 12th, the Lithuanian Government obtained from the Russians the city and territory which had been thus abandoned. The Lithuanian Government occupied the city on July 14th. The frontier, as fixed by the Treaty of Moscow, between Lithuania and Russia left to Lithuania Vilna, Lida and Grodno and extended to the west as far as the Bobr within 30 km. of the Prussian frontier, crossing the Curzon line.The position in September, 1920, was critical owing to the presence of Lithua-nian troops to the west of the Curzon line. The Poles, moreover, accused the Lithuanian Government of a breach of neutrality in the war between Poland and the Soviets.First Measures : The Line of Demarcation and the Military Commission of Control.The Council did not, at this stage, endeavour to arrange a final settlement of the dispute, but tried to obtain the provisional acceptance by the parties of a line of demarcation in the zones of occupation and to prevent any hostile acts between their troops. Owing to the state of war then existing between Poland and Soviet Russia and the occupation of a part of Lithuania by Soviet troops, it was difficult to secure a recognition of the neutrality of the territory in question.As a result of the intervention of the Council, Lithuania accepted, as a provisional line of demarcation, the frontier fixed by the Supreme Council in 1919, and undertook to withdraw her troops from the territory west of this line;, while Poland promised to respect the neutrality of the territory occupied by Lithuania to. the east of the line on condition that this neutrality was equally respected by the Government of the Soviets.The Council appointed a Military Commission of Control under Colonel Chardigny, which proceeded to the occupied districts, secured the withdrawal of the Polish and Lithuanian troops on either side of the line of demarcation, and arranged an armistice along the whole front. First, the Polish troops had driven the Soviet Army from Grodno and from Lida, and an armistice, with peace preliminaries, had been signed at Riga between Poland and the Soviet Republic. Secondly, on October 8th, General Zeligowski, at the head of a division, had- entered Vilna and proclaimed a Government under the title of the " Government of Central Lithuania."In these circumstances the delegates of Poland and Lithuania again appeared before the Council in Brussels in October 1920. The Polish Government repre-sented that it was not responsible for what had occurred at Vilna. It had repu-diated General Zeligowski and had declared that he was acting as a rebel. The Polish Republic could not, however, intervene forcibly against General Zeli-gowski, since his initiative had received the unanimous support of Polish public opinion. The Polish Government claimed that the districts where General Zeli-gowski had assumed control would, if allowed to settle their political destiny, decide to become attached to Poland rather than to Lithuania.Arrangements for a Plebiscite.After considerable discussion, the representatives of Poland and Lithuania accepted a proposal of the Council that a plebiscite should be held under the aus-pices of the League, whereby the inhabitants of the disputed territory might freely express their wishes concerning their adherence either to Lithuania or to Poland. It was understood that the Council would determine the area within which the plebiscite should be held and the conditions necessary to ensure free-dom of voting. It was also understood that the Council would decide what, mea-sures should be taken for the withdrawal or disarmament of any troops within the disputed area.The Council, during its session held in Geneva in November, 1920, still hoped that it would be possible to arrange for a plebiscite, and took steps for the organi-sation of international forces to be despatched to Vilna in order to ensure a free expression of the popular opinion.It soon, however, became obvious from the attitude of the parties that it would be difficult to arrive at a settlement of the dispute in this direction. The Military Commission under Colonel Chardigny was resisted in its efforts to pro-cure a demobilisation of the Lithuanian army and in its attempts to obtain the information which was indispensable for the organisation of the plebiscite. The Military Commission was equally unable to obtain a reduction of the forces of General Zeligowski. In spite of the repudiation of General Zeligowski by the Polish Government, his effectives, which did not exceed 20,000 men when he entered Vilna on October 8th, 1920, amounted to 50,000 men at the end of No-november. Repeated requests for demobilisation presented by the Military Corn-mission were disregarded and the Council was reluctantly compelled to note that a regular policy of obstruction was being followed.In February the detachment of international police had not yet started owing to the reluctance of the two parties, and it was clear that the plebiscite would involve a long delay.The Brussels Conference.In these circumstances the Council during its 12th session held at Paris from February 21st to March 4th, 1921, asked the two parties if they wod agree to meet informally at Brussels under the presidency of M. Hymans, and negotiate, directly with one another in his presence in order that a complete and final settle-ment of all the questions at issue, if possible, be reached. It was understood that the two parties would meet on a footing of complete equality.The discussions between the two parties during the Conference at Brussels concerning the future of Vilna were briefly summarised as follows in a report subsequently presented to the Council by M. Hymans : k II suffira de dire que les Lithuaniens invoquent 1'ancienne his-toire du Grand-Duche de Lithuanie, et le Traite de Moscou du 12 juillet 1920 par lequel les Soviets ont renonce en faveur de la Lithuanie a la souverainete russe sur Vilna et son territoire ; ils assurent que les Lithua-niens constituent, avec les Blancs-Russiens, la population autochtone de ce territoire, quoique une partie d'entre eux ne parlent pas la langue lithuanienne, et que les habitants de langue polonaise ne depassent pas 20 pour cent de la population totale des regions contestees ; enfin que le bassin du Niemen forme une unite economique dont Vilna est le centre naturel, et qui ne peut etre divisee sans que cette ville et sa province deperissent. It is not a plan for a federal union ; still less is it a plan for complete political fusion. It is a plan under which the two States, while retaining their independence and sovereignty unimpaired, enter into a friendly association for the pro-. motion of their common interests. It is a plan based on the view that Lithuania can hardly, in present circumstances, expect to maintain a splendid isolation, but that she has everything to gain by co-operation with Poland, just as Poland has everything to gain by association with her. We do not see that the association of Lithuania with Poland, as we propose, need in any way prejudice the friendly relations which the Government of Kovno may wish to secure with the neighbouring States of Latvia and Esthonia; ' Nor do we propose that the association between Poland and Lithuania should be strict and unelastic. PASSAGE OF INTERNATIONAL TROOPS THROUGHSWITZERLAND.The French Government, entrusted by the Council with the task of orga-recognising the transport of the international detachment intended to maintain order in the contested territory of Vilna during the preparation for a plebiscite, was authorised to ask the interested Governments on behalf of the Council for per-mission to despatch these troops over their territory. A request to this effect was addressed to the Governments of Switzerland, Austria and Czecho-Slovakia.The Swiss Government replied that it was unable to grant the necessary permission on the ground that it did not believe that the decision of the Council to hold a plebiscite had received the full assent of the two parties, and it feared that, if it granted the required permission, it would be obliged to withdraw it at a later date, if the Government of the Soviets should make an attack on the territory of Vilna and if the police operations undertaken by the Council should thus be transformed into military operations.The Council, during its 12th session, invited M. Dunant, the Swiss Minister in Paris, to attend and to explain to the Council the point of view of the Swiss Government. The attention of the Swiss Minister was drawn to the great moral injury which had been caused to the League by the decision of his Government and regret was expressed that the Federal Council had taken its decision without giving the Council of the League an opportunity of explaining under what condi tions the despatch of troops would eventually be undertaken.At a meeting of the Council held on March 4th, M. Dunant declared that there had been a misunderstanding. D'autre part, le representant de 1'Autriche s's'engage a ce que le droit d'expulsion ne. fut pas exerce contre tous ceux qui revendiquaient le droit d'option conformement au Traite de Saint-Germain, tant que les autorites competentes n'auraient pas statue sur leur cas. THE EXPULSION OF JEWISH REFUGEES FROM AUSTRIA.On September 9th, 1919, the Government of Lower Austria published a decree, requiring all former nationals of the Austro-Hungarian Monarchy who were not resident in German Austria previous to August 1st, 1914, and who had not acquired Austrian nationality after that date, to leave the territory of German Austria before September 20th, 1919, under pain of forcible expulsion.In a memorandum dated February 27th, the Polish delegation to the League of Nations, drawing attention to this decree, stated that the Austrian autho-rities had enforced it rigorously only in the case of Polish nationals, more parti-cularly the Eastern Galician Jews. The number of Galician Jews in Austria was at that time about 50,000 and they had all received, individually, orders of expulsion. The Polish Government desired the Council of the League of Nations to intervene in order to prevent the Austrian authorities from compelling persons who did not wish to return to Poland to submit to this decree and to cross the Polish frontier against their will.The Council considered the matter during its 12th Session, when the repre-sentatives of Poland and Austria attended the Council and presented statements of their views.The representative of Austria pleaded that it was the duty of Austria to repatriate all persons whose residence in the country was injurious to the Austrian people.Upon the advice of the Council, the representatives of Austria and of Poland met together and after some discussion, in which representatives of the Council participated, came to an agreement. It was recognised that from a legal point of view Austria had an undeniable right to expel the Galician Jews, and that Poland was, in a certain sense, responsible for the population of the former Austro-Hungarian territory which it occupied in the name of the Allies. It was noted that the number of Jews so far expelled by the Austrian police was only 140 and that only 600 other persons had left Austria owing to the decree. It was admitted that the condition of Austria must be taken into consideration. Her population lacked food and accused the refugees of intensifying the general distress.It was further noted that from 15,000 to 20,000 of the refugees had claimed the right of option to remain in Austria under the Treaty of St. Germain and that Austrian tribunals would have to pass judgment individually on these requests.In these circumstances, the representative of Poland undertook that the Polish authorities in Austria would consider, without delay, any lists of persons whose repatriation the Austrian authorities desired to effect. The represen-tative of Austria undertook, on his side, that the right of expulsion would not be exercised against individuals whose claims to exercise the right of option under the Treaty of St. Germain were under consideration until the competent authorities had reported on each case. He further undertook that special consideration would be given in the case of persons regularly employed, of sick and aged persons, of persons whose homes had been destroyed, and of certain classes of students. The excellent progress made was partly the result of a Conference which had been held on January 17th, at which representatives of the German, Soviet, Latvian and Lithuanian Governments were present. THE FINANCES OF THE LEAGUE.(a) The Budgets of the League. . .The first three budgets of the League, which covered the period from the beginning of the League to December 31st, 1921, were duly approved by the first Assembly on Deceniber 17th, 1920.The third budget, which covered the period January 1st to December 31st, 1921, was admittedly only a provisional estimate. Already in June it had become apparent to the Council that certain appropriations in the third budget would prove insufficient, while in respect of others there would be a surplus. The Council accordingly exercised the powers conferred on it by the recommendation of the Assembly of December 17th, 1920, to sanction certain transfersVfrom one item to another in the same chapter without increasing the total sum voted for the financial year. The Council has also approved of certain advances made from the working capital fund in order to finance various activities of the Financial Section of the Provisional Economic and Financial Committee. These expenses were incurred in connection with the international credits scheme and the relief of Austria.The fourth budget of the League, which covers the financial year 1922, was, in conformity with the recommendations of the first Assembly, prepared three months before the annual session of the Assembly, and was submitted to the Council during its June session. The budget is divided into seven Chap-ters :(1) Assembly and Council Meetings.(2) General Services of the Secretariat.(3) Special Organisations of the League.(4) Capital Expenditure.(5) Working Capital Replacement.(6) The Permanent Court of International Justice.(7) The International Labour Office.More particulars are given in the fourth budget than in the previous budgets, and detailed explanations are submitted in notes and schedules. Since the budget was established for a period which does not begin until seven months after the time when the estimates were prepared, the Secretary-General may be obliged to ask the Assembly to sanction certain modifications when the budget is discussed.In accordance with a desire expressed by the Committee of Inquiry into the Staff and Organisation of the Secretariat, each of the special organisations of the League has separate estimates in the 1922 budget, and it is hoped that the Chairmen of the Committees of these organisations will be prepared to explain and defend before the Assembly, if necessary, the budgets of their respective organisations.The fourth budget, as at present drafted, estimates the expenditure for 1922 at 23,768,846 gold francs, as compared with 21,250,000 gold francs author-ised in the budget for 1921. The slight increase in the budget for 1922 is due, in a large measure, to the fact that owing to the gradual improvement in value of the various national currencies it is expected that more gold francs will be required to buy the same number of Swiss francs, French francs, or pounds ster-. ling than in 1921. That decision, however, should not be considered as an acquiescence on the part of His Imperial Japanese Majesty's Government in the submission of Japanese subjects to a discriminatory and disadvantageous treatment in. the mandated territories ; nor have they thereby discarded their claim that the rights and interests enjoyed by Japanese subjects in these territories in the past should be fully respected." ARMENIA.The first Assembly, by a resolution adopted on November 18th, 1920, entrusted the Council with the duty of safeguarding the future of Armenia, referring for advice, if it should be necessary, to the Members of the League.The position of Armenia was, however, entirely changed when the Assembly separated. The Armenian Government which had appealed to the Assembly, had ceased to exist, and had been replaced by a Government in close relationship with the Soviet Government of Russia.President Wilson, to whom, under the Treaty of Sevres, the task of fixing the frontiers between Armenia and Turkey was entrusted, announced his decision on January 2nd. This decision allotted to Armenia an extensive territory, inclu-ding, Trebizond, Erzigun, Erzerum, Mush, Bitlis and Van.The Council during its meeting held on February 25th, 1921, considered how it might best give effect to the resolution of the Assembly.It decided that, until the situation in Asia Minor had become clearer, and, in particular, until the various questions in regard to the Treaty of Sevres had been settled by the Allied Powers, no further action was possible. Meanwhile, it en-trusted to the Secretary-General the duty of watching developments in Armenian affairs, with a view to preparing any subsequent decisions which might be neces-sary on the part of the Council.The Philarmenian League, in a letter dated June 20th, again directed the attention of the Council to the position in Armenia. It was stated in this letter that the Treaty of Alexandrinopol had been confirmed by a Russo-Turkish con-ference at Moscow in March and that virtually the whole of the Armenian Re-public was in the hands either of the nationalist Turks or of the Soviets. VIII. THE RELIEF OF CHILDREN IN COUNTRIES AFFECTED BYTHE WAR.The first Assembly, on December 15th, 1920, adopted the following resolution : " The Assembly, being desirous of giving its support to the urgent work of rescuing children in the countries affected by the war, invites the Council to consider as soon as possible the means by which the moral authority of the League of Nations may best assist this work which is being done in the cause of humanity. "The Council, considering this resolution on February 23rd, 1921, noted that the work of relieving the children was already being most effectively carried out by various voluntary organisations, and decided that there was no occasion for the League of Nations to take any active part. THE COMMISSION OF ENQUIRY TO THE TERRITORIES OF THE FORMER OTTOMAN EMPIRE.The Assembly, by a resolution of December 15th, 1920, invited the Council to appoint a commission of enquiry to inform it as to the present situation in Armenia, Asia Minor, Turkey and in the adjacent territories regarding deported women and children.The Council considered the appointment of this Commission at. its meeting held at Paris.on February 22nd, 1921. It was decided that the Members of the Council would write to their respective Governments requesting them to assist these persons in all possible ways.In execution of this decision, Dr. Kennedy, Miss Emma Cushman and Madame Gaulis were invited to conduct the enquiry and to report the result to the Council. On decida alors :l0 que les proces-verbaux des seances seraient publies en volume, aussitot que possible apres la cloture de la session ;20 que le Secretariat assurerait la publication immediate d'un compte rendu des debats prealablement approuve par les Membres du Conseil.La tradition, qui consistait a tenir des seances publiques a la fin de la session pour entendre la lecture des rapports et des resolutions adoptes, a ete abandonnee. Hymans faisait la declara-tion suivante, a ce sujet:n Quant aux seances publiques finales telles qu'elles ont eulieu jusqu'a present, elles n'ont souvent eveille que peu d'interet. The Council further decided that its minutes should be published on the day when they were communicated to the Members of the League.When the Council assembled for its 13th session in Geneva, it was decided on June 17th that the minutes of the Council should be published daily, after approval by the Council, on the understanding that no minute dealing with any particular subject would be published until the discussion of that subject was completed and a final decision reached. Objections to this procedure were raised at a subsequent meeting of the Council held on June 20th, when it was decided :(1) That the minutes of the session should be published in volume form as soon after the close of the session as possible ;(2) That the Secretariat should prepare a summary of the debates for immediate publication. On peut diviser les questions traitees par cette Commission en : l0 Questions relevant principalement du Comite financier ; 20 Questions relevant principalement du Comite economique; 30 Questions interessant les deux Comites.I0 Questions relevant principalement du Comtte financier.a) Le projet des credits inter nalionaux.Le 14 decembre 1920, le Conseil a approuve le projet de credits internatio-naux, connu sous le nom de projet Ter Meulen, et a charge le Comite financier de prendre les mesures necessaires pour le mettre a execution sans delai.Gomme suite a cette decision, Sir Drummond Drummond-Fraser a ete nomme organisateur des credits internationaux en fevrier 1921, sous la direc-tion generate d'un sous-comite du Comite financier. It will be convenient to divide the Report of the Committee's work into ; (1) Subjects dealt with primarily by the Financial Commit!ee ; (2) Subjects dealt with primarily by the Economic Committee ; (3) Subjects of joint interest.(1) Subjects dealt with primarily by the Financial Committee.(a) International Credits Scheme.On December 14th, 1920, the Council approved the International Credits Scheme known as the Ter Meulen Scheme and entrusted to the Financial Com-mittee the duty of taking the steps necessary to apply this scheme without delay.In execution of this decision, Sir Drummond Drummond-Fraserwas appointed Organiser of International Credits in February, 1921, to work under the general direction of a sub-committee of the Financial Committee. He immediately approached the competent representatives of those Governments which might be interested in the scheme, either as borrowers or as lenders. At the same time, he has taken every opportunity of drawing the attention of financial and commer-cial circles in various countries to the advantages which would be derived from the scheme. The Committee was able to report to the Council in June, 1921, that, as a result of the Organiser's consultation with the various Governments, hope might be entertained that the International Credits Scheme would, on the whole, be favourably received and would render the services which might justly be expected from it.The Organiser has pointed out that the best means of ensuring the success of the scheme would be the existence of an effective demand for Ter Meulen bonds among the nationals of exporting countries. The efforts of the Organiser have therefore been largely directed to securing a proper understanding of the advantages of the scheme in all possible borrowing countries. These efforts have had distinctly successful results. On June 14th, the "World Cotton Conference at Liverpool and Manchester passed two unanimous resolutions : one stating the view that, at the moment, the Ter Meulen Scheme offered the best instrument for the transmission of imports into impoverished countries by exporters in other countries, and urging all engaged in the cotton industry and in the financing of it to avail themselves of the Scheme ; and the second/ expressing the strong approval of the Conference of the Financial Committee's scheme for the rehabi-litation of Austria.Further, the General Congress of the International Chamber of Commerce, held in London on June 27th to July 1st, passed a unanimous Resolution, recog-recognising the necessity of credits under Government auspices for the reconstruction of impoverished countries, and declaring the readiness of the Congress to support the Ter Meulen Scheme as modified and put into operation by the Financial Committee of the League of Nations.Another important practical advance has been made by enlisting in Great Britain the active support of the Co-operative Wholesale Society. This organisa-tion has addressed to all Societies in other countries a circular, stating that it is prepared to grant them credits for the shipment of approved goods, provided that they deposit Ter Meulen Bonds as security.(6) The Relief of Austria.As a result of a Conference held in London from March 12th to March 17th, 1921, between the Financial Delegates of the Supreme Council of the AlliedPowers under the chairmanship of Mr. Austen Chamberlain, and Financial Delegates of the Austrian Republic, the purpose of which Conference was to examine the best means of restoring the financial situation of Austria, the Financial Committee was called upon by the Supreme Council of the Allied Powers to examine the possibility of adapting the International Credits Scheme'to the special require-ments of Austria. Le Comite financier a adresse, le 4 avril, au Conseil supreme, par i'interme-diaire du President du Conseil de la Societe des Nations, une premiere reponse relative aux conditions qu'il lui semblait necessaire de voir realiser avant qu'on put entreprendre de retablir le credit del'Autriche. Cette reponse declarait, en outre, que le Comite s'occupait de recueillir tous les renseignements necessaires en vue de cette tache. Le Comite etait d'avis que l'application du projet Ter Meulen a 1'Autriche dependait des efforts que 1'Autriche elle-meme etait prete a faire pour mettre de 1'ordiv dans ses finances et pour fournir des ages acceptables en ga-rantie des credits qui pouivaient lui etre accordes. Le Comite faisait, en outre, connaitre aux Gouvernements interesses son opinion au sujet du nombre d'annees pendant lesquelles ils devaient suspendre leurs privileges (cette mesure avait ete acceptee en principe a la Conference de Londres mentionnee ci-dessus). En outre, le Comite financier exposait les conditions auxquelles devait etre subordonnee cette suspension. De Tavis du Comite, la periode de suspension des privil-ges ne saurait etre inferieure a 20 ans. De plus, les emprunts et credits de toute nature contractes par le Gouvernement autrichien, avec 1'approbation prealable du Comite financier au cours des cinq premieres ; nnees, devraient jouir pour leur service, pendant une periode allant jusqu'a leur complet amortissement, meme si cette periode devait etre superieure a 20 ans, d'un droit de priorite absolue par rapport aux droits et privileges mis en suspens.Apres avoir examine les conclusions d'une delegation, qui s'etait rendue a Vienne pour etudier sur place la situation financiere et economique de 1'Autriche et recevoir les propositions du Gouvernement autrichien, le Comite redigea un rapport definitif eontenant sa reponse finale au Conseil supreme. Ce rapport, adresse le 3 juin par le President du Conseil de la Societe au Conseil supreme des Puissances aliiees, concluait a la possibilite d'entreprendre le relevement de 1'Autrir che, conformement au plan elabore par le Gouvernement autrichien avec lc consen-tement de tous les partis politiques. Le rapport indiquait egalement la possibilite de se procurer des fonds suffisants, sous forme d'emprunts temporaires a 1'etranger et de garanties au moyen de bons Ter Meulen, lorsque les privileges sur 1'Autriche que possedent les Gouvernements interesses auraient ete suspendus. La mise a execution du pro jet dependait done de la decision de ces Gouvernements.Le Comite declare egalement qu'il a recu 1'assurance que Ton pourrait disposer d'avances temporaires qui seraient faites dans les conditions indi-quees par le rapport. Ces avances suffiraient a assurer la mise en oeuvre pen-dant quelques mois du programme de reforme financiere du Gouvernement autrichiens-chien. Ce programme, tel qu'il est esquisse dans le rapport de la Commission d'enquete envoyee par le Comite a Vienne, est hardi et complet. II comprend a 1'interieur une reforme radicale des finances, remission d'un emprunt interieur pour assurer 1'equilibre du budget, la creation d'une nouvelle banque d'emission independante et la reiorme monetaire. A 1'exterieur, il envisage 1'ohtention de credits etrangers pour lesquels le Gouvernement autrichien offre des garanties suffisantes et la creation d un controle international.On ne peut encore expOser en detail les mesures prises a la suite de ce rapport du 3 juin. Actuellement, dix gouvernements ont accepte de suspenclre toutes leurs hypotheques sur 1'Autriche,.-En juillet 1921, la Conference des ambassadeurs, agissant au nom clu Conseil supreme, a decide de faire faire une demarche par les representants dipiomatiques des Puissances aliiees a "Washington, en vue d'obtenir des Etats-Unis qu*ils consen-tent a la suspension des privileges sur l'Autriche, qu'ils tiennent des obligations souscrites pour les credits de secours.c) Credits de finition.A sa premiere session, le Comite financier, d'accord avec le Comite economiquc, a confie a une Commission d'experts juridiques et d'hommes d'affaires le soin d'examiner les possibilites d'application du systeme des credits de finition. D'apres ce systeme, les matieres premieres continuent, au cours de leurs transformations successives, a servir de garanties aux avances consenties. Le remboursement de ces credits de finition constitue une premiere hypotheque sur les sommes realisees par la vente des articles manufactures.Cette enquete, comme beaucoup d'autres travaux des deux Comites, avait son point de depart dans un voeu de la Conference financiere internationale de Bruxelles. The Financial Committee transmitted, on April 4th, to the Supreme Council, through the President of the Council of the League, a preliminary reply laying down the conditions which appeared to it to be necessary before the restoration of Austrian credit could be undertaken and stating that the Committee was taking steps to collect all the information necessary for the fulfilment of its task. The Committee realised that the application of the scheme to Austria must depend on the efforts which Austria herself was prepared to make to introduce order into her finances, and to assign acceptable assets as security for the credits to be granted. The Committee communicated to the Governments concerned its opinion in regard to the duration of the suspension of liens (which had been agreed to, in principle, at the London Meeting referred to above), and to the con-ditions to be attached thereto. In the opinion of the Committee, the period of the suspension of liens should not be less than 20 years. Further, until their repayment was completed, the Committee held that any loans or credits of any nature, contracted by the Austrian Government, with the previous approval of the Committee, during the first five years, should enjoy for the whole of its term, even if for longer than twenty years, a right of absolute priority over all rights and liens suspended..After having considered the conclusions of a Delegation which it had sent to Vienna to enquire on the spot into the financial and economic situation of Austria, and to hear the proposals of the Austrian Government, the Committee drew up a definitive report, submitting its final reply to the Supreme Council. This report, which was sent on June 3rd by the President of the Council of the League to the Supreme Council of the Allied Powers, established the possibility of undertaking the relief of Austria, in accordance with a plan drawn up by the Austrian Govern-ment with the consent of all political parties in the country. The report also indi-cated that sufficient funds in the form of temporary loans obtained abroad and secu-rities by Ter Meulen bonds might be forthcoming when the liens on Austria in favour of the Governments concerned had been suspended. The execution of the scheme was therefore dependent upon the decision of these Governments.. The report of the Committee also states the fact that definite assurances have been received by them that temporary advances will be available on the "basis indicated in the report, sufficient to enable the Austrian Governments programme of financial reform t. operate for some months. The Austrian Govern-menfs programme for reform, as outlined in the report cf the Committee's Commission of Enquiry in Vienna, is drastic and comprehensh e. It includes, internally, the complete revision of Government finances, the issue of an internal loan so as to secure the balancing of the Budget, the establishment of a new and independent Bank of Issue and the reform of the currency. Externally, it con-templates foreign credits for which sufficient guarantees are offered by the Aus-trian Government, and an international control is envisaged.The further action arising out of the Committee's report of June 3rd cannot yet be detailed in its entirety. At the date of the present report ten Governments have agreed to suspend any liens which they may hold On Austria.Further, in July, 921, the Council of Ambassadors, acting for the Supreme Council f the Allied Powers, decided to . pproach the Government of the United States through the Allied diplomatic representatives in Washington with the object of obtaining the consent of the United States Government to the suspension-sion of American claims upon Austria in respect of relief credits.(c) Finishing Credits.At its first Session, the, Financial Committee, acting in agreement with the Economic Committee, entrusted a Committee of legal experts and business, men with the task of investigating the possibility of : pplying the system of Finishing Credits, a system under which raw materials continue through their successive transformations to serve- as security for the credits which have been granted, while the reimbursement of the credit is a first charge upon the sums realise by the sale of the manufactured article.This enquiry, like many of the activities of both Committees, was a result of a i-ecommend,ation of the International Financial Conference of Brussels Au cours de sa reunion a Geneve, au debut de fevrier 1921, la Commission cTexperts juridiques et d'hommes cVaffaires estima que les legislations actuelles etaient suffisantes ou pouvaient etre modifiees pour permettre 1'emploi du systeme des credits de finition.Le rapport de la Commission d'experts a la Commission economique et finan-ciere signalait les difficultes juridiques du probleme et la necessite de consulter les milieux d'affaires des difierents pays sur 1'aspect economique du projet. La Commission economique et financiere, apres avoir approuve ce rapport, qu'elle considere comme un expose remarquable de la situation en ce qui conccrne les credits de finition, a prie les membres du Comite economique de se charger de consulter les milieux d'affaires de leurs pays respectifs. Les renseignements obtenus jusqu'a present ne laissent guere de doute sur le peu de faveur que semble devoir rencontrer ce systeme de credits.d) Aulres questions soulevees par la Conference finunciere Internationale de Bruxelles.Le Comite financier a commence F examen des rapports rediges par quelques-uns de ses membres au sujet des questions suivantes, soulevees par les resolutions de la Conference financiere internationale de Bruxelles.Double taxation, en particulier double impot sur le revenu.Traitement de reciprocite pour les succursales des banques etrangeres dans ies diff erents pays.Accord international a propos des valeurs perdues, volees ou detruites.Reclamations des cletenteurs d'obligations dont le paiement des interets a ete suspendu.e) Publicite a donner aux decisions de la Conference financiere inlernaiionale deBruxelles.Le Comite financier, au cours de Fannee, s;est efforce de donner la plus large publicite possible aux decisions de la Conference financicre internationale de Bruxelles.ii. Questions relevant principalement du Comite economique.a) Enqueie sur la situation economique generale.Le Comite economique s'est vu oblige, des sa premiere reunion, de renseigner le Conseil sur la question si importante et si complexe de la fourniture aux divers pays des denrees alimentaires et des matieres premieres necessaires a leur pros-perite et parfois meme a leur existence. Pour etre en mesure de remplir ce role consultatif, le Comite economique devait commencer par etablir un tableau d'ensemble de la situation economique actuelle et par completer sa documentation sur certains, points.Un premier questionnaire fut done adresse aux differents gouvernements en Janvier 1921, les priant d'envoyer des renseignements sur les points suivants-,a) Restrictions d'importation et d'exportation (licences, prix d'exportation,reserves pour la consommation interieure, mesures contre le dumping, etc.);b) Monopoles ;c) Concurrence deloyale.Un second questionnaire fut envoye, en fevrier 1921, pour prier les gouver-nements de donner tous les renseignements qu'ils possedent sur leurs stocks de denrees alimentaires et de matieres premieres, aim d'arriver a une vue d'ensernble de la situation.Le Secretariat a deja recu un certain nombre de reponses et le Comite econo-mique presentera son rapport en temps opportun. Subjects dealt with primarily by the Economic Committee.(a) Enquiry into the world's economic situation.The Economic Committee was, at its first meeting, confronted with the necessity of advising the Council upon the very large and complex question of ths- supply to the various countries of the food stuffs and raw materials necessary for their well-being, and, in some cases, even for their existence. In order adequately to fulfil the advisor role with which it had been invested, it was necessary for the Committee, as a first step, to draw up a general summary of existing economic conditions, and to supplement the data at its disposal with regard to certain aspects of the question.With this object in view, a preliminary Questionnaire was addressed to the different Governments, in.January, 1921, asking for information on the following points : (a) Import and export restrictions (licences, export prices, reserves for home consumption, anti-dumping bills, etc.).(b) Monopolies. .(c) Unfair competition.A further Questionnaire was also addressed to the Governments in February, 1.921, requesting them to give any information in their power with regard to their stocks of foodstuffs and raw materials which might tend to throw light on the situation throughout the world. . Conference generale pour la discussion des questions financieres. (b) Finishing Credits.For particulars of the work accomplished under this head, see Section (c) of the work of the Financial Committee.In addition, certain members of the Economic Committee have undertaken enquiries in industrial circles in their own country, to ascertain what reception the Finishing Credits Scheme would be likely to receive. Subjects of General Interest.(a) Statistical and other Publications.At its first meeting the Economic Committee, in agreement with the Financial Committee, decided bo recommend to the Council that the League of Nations should take over the publication of the Monthly Bulletin of Statistics (a collection of indices illustrating commercial and industrial movements in the various coun-tries), previously issued by the British Board of Trade and by the French Ministry of Commerce, under the auspices of the Supreme Economic Council. THE HEALTH ORGANISATION.The resolution on the Health Organisation of the League adopted by the Assembly on December 10th, 1920, provided :(1) For the establishment of a General Committee, of which the Office international d'Hygiene publique at Paris was to serve as the founda-tion ; . Unfortunately, the Office international cTHygiene publique found itself unable to accept the invitation of the Council to appoint representatives to sit on the proposed Provisional Technical Committee, on the ground that the United States, which was a member of the Office International, was not willing that any international organisation, on which it was represented, should in any way be attached to the League. This Committee, which consisted of the British, French, Italian and Japanese delegates, a representative of the International Labour Office and a representative of the League of Red Cross Societies, passed a resolution affirming that, as a result of the refusal of the Office international d'Hygiene publique, its composition did not conform with the reso-lution of the Council adopted at Paris and therefore did not allow of the execu-tion of its programme. It noted the refusal of the Office international dTIygiene publique to participate, and decided that, in view of this refusal, the Provisional Technical Committee should be composed of not more than twelve persons, individually invited to sit, on the strength of their technical qualifications and not of their nationality, together with a representative nominated by the Inter-national Labour Office and a representative nominated by the League of Red Cross Societies.The Council realised that it was important that there should be co-operation between this Committee and that of the Office international dTIygiene publique. The Secretary-General was, at the same time, requested to provide for a secretariat of the Provisional Technical Committee on the same lines as those adopted by the Council and by the Assembly for the Economic and Financial Committee.
