THE WORK OF THE COMMITTEES AND CONFERENCES APPOINTED OR CONVENED BY THE COUNCIL IN EXE-CUTION OF THE RESOLUTIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE ASSEMBLY.I. - THE COMMITTEE OF ENQUIRY INTO THE STAFF AND ORGANISATION OF THE SECRETARIAT.The Appointment of the Committee.The first Assembly adopted a recommendation on December 17th, 1920, requesting the Council to take the necessary steps to appoint as soon as possible a small Committee of experts to examine the organisation of the permanent Secretariat of the League and the International Labour Office. The Committee was to consider " all factors connected with the organisation, method of work, efficiency, number, salaries and allowances of the staff and with the general expenditure of the whole organisation."' The Committee of Enquiry was appointed by the Council under a resolu-iton adopted on February 21st, 1921. The Committee was notified that its report should be placed in possession of the Members of the League by July 1st, 1921.The Committee began its preliminary investigations on April 18th and pre-sented its report on May 7th, 1921.The Report of the Committee.The Committee considered that the Secretariat of the League had grasped its duties correctly, keeping well within the bounds prescribed by the Covenant and that it was soundly and scientifically organised.The Committee was of opinion that, while the average of salaries was on the high side in comparison with those paid in government departments of long standing, they were fully justified during the critical period of organisation. It appended a schedule of salaries under which members of the Secretariat might henceforth be recruited at somewhat lower figures than those hitherto generally obtained, but which might permit of officers so recruited rising by annual increases to approximately the same salaries as those paid to the officers already appointed. The Committee further recommended that the salaries should vary with the cost of living and suggested that a Salaries Adjustment Committee should be appointed to adjust the salaries given in the schedule to the fluctuations in the cost of living. The Committee also recommended that the salaries of the staff should be paid in Swiss francs.The Committee considered that the subsistence allowances paid to members of the Secretariat when proceeding on duty to places away from the headquarters of the League should be slightly reduced. It suggested that these allowances should be 60 Swiss francs a day for the higher officers, 40 Swiss francs for the members of sections and the heads of administrative departments, and 30 Swiss francs for the clerical staff generally. The Committee further recommended the establishment of an entertainment fund to which members of the Secretariat might have recourse whenever authorised by a special officer appointed for the purpose. In return for the right to draw on this fund, the higher officers of the League should be asked to surrender a whole or part of their frais de representation.The Committee pointed out that, if the League were transferred to a town such as Brussels, Fontainebleau, Turin or Vienna an immediate economy would economie immediate, en raison du cout de la vie et du change. Elle declara egale-ment que Ton pourrait eviter des depenses inutiles en tenant a Geneve les reunions du Conseil, des Commissions et des Conferences, sauf impossibilite.La Commission recommande de donner au personnel du Secretariat, autant que possible et sans plus attendre, des engagements a terme defini, pour une longue periode, comportant une retraite, sur le modele des administrations gouvernemen-tales, et d'operer le recrutement, dans la mesure du possible, par voie de concours. La Commission pense notamment que le Secretariat devrait etre compose aussi largement que possible de membres attires par la perspective d'une carriere defi-nitive a la Societe des Nations.La Commission recommande de nommer une Commission de controle de qua-tre a six membres designes par le Conseil parmi les Etats Membres de la Societe. Cette Commission se reunirait chaque annee a Geneve et examinerait le budget de la Societe pour 1'exercice suivant, ainsi que les comptes de 1'exercice financier precedent. La Commission d'enqu te propose, en outre, de nommer, pour une periode de cinq ans, un expert financier choisi dans 1'une des administrations financieres nationales, pour servir de rapporteur de la Commission de controle.Les recommandations generales de la Commission s'appliquent aussi bien au Bureau international du Travail qu'au Secretariat, surtout en ce qui regarde les traitements, les indemnites et le controle financier.La Commission propose que le Conseil d'administration du Bureau interna-tional du Travail designe qualre de ses membres, charges d'aller presenter a la Commission de controle, dont la creation est recommandee, les propositions bud-getaires du Bureau international du Travail pour 1'exercice financier suivant.Action du Conseil.Le Conseil prit acte du rapport de la Commission d'enquete, le 17 juin. II decida de le faire transmettre par le Secretaire general a tous les Membres de la Societe et de le soumettre a 1'examen de 1'Assemblee. It also stated that unnecessary expenditure might be avoided by holding the meetings of the Council and of Committees and Conferences at Geneva, except when it was impracticable to do so.The Committee recommended that the staff of the Secretariat should, as far as possible and without delay, be given definite terms of engagement for a long period and pension rights on the model of persons employed in Government departments, and that it should be appointed as far as possible by competitive selection. COMMITTEE ON THE ALLOCATION OF THE EXPENSESOF THE LEAGUE.Appointment of the Committee.The first Assembly, by a recommendation adopted on December 17th, requested the Council to appoint a special committee of five members, including the Swiss delegate of the Universal Postal Union, to investigate the question of the allocation of the expenses of the League with a view to the devising of an equitable scheme. The Council appointed this Committee on December 14th, 1920, before the first Assembly separated. The Committee was composed as follows :M. Reveillaud (Chairman). M. Barboza Carneiro. M. Alfred Georg.M. Gluckstadt (who was replaced at' the earlier meetingsby M. Sthyr and at the last meeting by M. de Kaufmann). Sir Henry Strakosch.The Members of the League were notified by the Secretary-General on May 2nd, 1921, that the Committee had been unable to present a definitive report to the Council on March 31st, 1921, the date contemplated in the Assem-bly's resolution. At the request of the Council, the Committee continued its study of the question and were able on June 10th, 1921, to report to the Council unanimously.Conclusions of the Committee.The question before the Committee had already been studied in 1920 by a Committee of the International Financial Conference at Brussels which held that the guiding principle for the allocation of the expenses of the League should be the capacity for payment of the various Members, and that, in the absence of a more satisfactory criterion of national resources, this capacity should be gauged by taking into, consideration total population as on December 31st, 1919, toge-ther with net revenue for the year 1913.The Allocation Committee, while realising that the indices of population and net revenue were not a fully reliable standard for establishing capacity for payment, formed the opinion that no other factor taken singly had the same intrinsic value as that afforded by the two indices recommended at Brussels, and that it would not be possible to arrive at any result in the short time at the dis-posal of the Committee, if it were to abandon the point of view previously adopted, and demand documents and statistics of an entirely new kind. La Commission s'est done servie, pour etablir son tableau de repartition, des indices de la population et du revenu net, sous reserve de certaines garanties et rectifications qui s'imposaient. Tenant compte, notamment, du fait que certains pays, situes hors d'Europe, ont une population indigene tres nombreuse, qui ne contribue que dans une proportion infime a augmenter les ressources de ces pays, la Commission a decide que, pour aucun Etat, le coefficient de la population ne pourrait depasser 5 % de F ensemble de la population des Etats Membres de la Societe. La Commission a reconnu que c'etait la une solution empirique qui ne saurait remedier aux difficultes que souleve la question des petits Etats tropicaux. Elle a presente son rapport comme un classement approximate qui ne pouvait etre, etant donne les circonstances, un travail scientifique, mais qui representait, a son avis, les dispositions les plus equitables qu'elle put proposer.La Commission a d'abord enregistre les chiffres les plus exacts qu'elle avait pu recueillir, tant pour 1'indice ((population w que pour 1'indice k revenu net * : elle a ensuite procede a un classement provisoire de tous les Membres de la Societe, d'apres 1'indice moyen qui resultait de ces deux facteurs. A la lumiere des rensei-gnements qu'elle possedait, elle a corrige ce classement, lorsqu'il lui est apparu qu'il constituait une injustice a Fegard de tel ou tel Etat. Finalement, la Commis-sion a groupe, par categories, les Etats dont la capacite contributive paraissait equitablement et raisonnablement comparable.La Commission a ensuite procede a la fixation du nombre d'unites a attribuer aux differents groupes, c'est-a-dire de la quote-part des depenses generates de la Society qui doit etre versee par chaque Etat, suivant le groupedans lequel il se trouve place. Le bareme actuel de 1'Union postale universelle est apparu a la Commission comme trop peu en rapport avec la capacite de paiement respective des Membres de la Societe. La Commission a egalement ecarte Fidee de determiner les coeffi-cients en prenant la moyenne exacte des indices des Etats classes dans le meme groupe. Finally, the Committee arranged the States in groups of States whose capacity to pay could be regarded as fairly and reasonably comparable.The Committee next proceeded to determine the number of units to be applied to the various groups, i. e., the proportion of the total expenditure of the League to be borne by each State according to the group in which it was placed. The present scale of the Universal Postal Union appeared to the Committee too little in accord with the respective capacities for payment of Members of the League. The Committee also rejected the idea of determining the coefficients required by taking the exact mean of the indices of each of the States in each group. The apparent mathematical exactitude of this method would be neces-sarily superficial in view of the uncertainty of the data ; and the Committee also felt that an equitable system of allocation should take account of such elements as the fact that the services of the League are equally at the disposal of all its Members, whether their revenues are large or small. The Committee eventually recommended a system occupying an intermediate position between the mathe-matical mean and the scale, of the Universal Postal Union, under which the respective groups would pay 90, 65, 35, 15, 10, 5, 2 units respectively. "At its Session held in Paris (February, 1921) the Military Commission (P.A.C.) adopted the following resolution :" According to Article 8 of the Covenant, the Members of the League undertake to interchange full and frank information as to the scale of their armaments, their military, naval and air programmes. In view of this undertaking, it appears superfluous and futile to set up a new system of supervision for the nations which have already signed that declaration. If the good faith of such an interchange of information is open to suspicion, would not a similar doubt arise in regard to the information which would be supplied by this organ of control ? Every nation is sovereign in its own territory, and it would itself direct any investigation which might be carried out there. VIII. THE INTERNATIONAL BLOCKADE COMMISSION.The first Assembly adopted on December 10th, 1921, the following resolution:" The Council should be asked to appoint an International Blockade Commission to consider the application of Article 16 of the Covenant; the Commission will report to the Council, which shall place the conclusions before the Assembly at its next session, for their acceptance, rejection, or amendment, without prejudice to any action that may have been provi-provisionally taken upon them. The Commission should not exceed eight in number, with power to summon experts to advise them, and not less than half its members should be persons representing States which have not a right to permanent membership of the Council. "The Council, by a resolution adopted in Paris on February 22nd, decided to ask the Governments of Cuba, Spain, Norway and Switzerland to appoint representatives to- sit on the Commission together with representatives of France, Great Britain, Italy and Japan.It was decided that, should the Commission desire the advice of experts on special points, it should refer to the Provisional Economic and Financial Committee, to the Permanent Advisory Commission for Military, Naval and Air Questions, and to the Secretariat of the League. The Council instructed the Secretary-General to ask each Member of the League to send information for the use of the Commission concerning the means at the disposal of the Member for carrying out the obligations arising out of Article 16 of the Covenant, together with any other information or memoranda likely to be of use in drafting and carrying out the programme suggested by the first Assembly.The Committee was constituted as follows :During its thirteenth session, the Council took note of these appointments the latest of which had been communicated to the Secretariat on June 15th.The Secretary-General wrote on February 25th and March 15th to the Mem-bers of the League asking them to send him the information required by the resolution of the Council of February 22nd, together with any public comment or explanatory statement regarding Articles 12-17 of the Covenant which were available or any published reports on the effect of the blockade enforced against the Central Powers during the war.Only nine Governments (Finland, France, Czecho-Slovakia, Great Britain, India, Norway, the Netherlands, Sweden and Switzerland) had replied to these demands when the Council met in June, and their replies did not form a sufficient basis for a general discussion of the question. The Secretary-General accordingly addressed to the Members a further appeal to communicate urgently as full replies as possible. GHAP1TRE iii.TRAVAIL DU SECRETARIAT.Le second des rapports qui doivent etre presentes a 1'Assemblee, aux termes de 1'article 4 du reglement, doit traiter du travail clu Secretariat et des mesures prises pour mettre a execution les decisions de 1'Assemblee.En realite, la tache du Secretariat consiste a preparer et a appliquer les deci-sions de 1'Assemblee, du Conseil et des autres organismes de la Societe. Les deux premiers chapitres du present rapport ont deja suffisamment expose la portee et la nature de ce travail. II ne semble pas utile de presenter sur ce sujet un rapport separe, ni d'essayer d'etablir une distinction qui n'existe pas en realite, ou qui, du moins, n'existe qu'a un degre tres limite, entre le travail du Secretariat et 1'activite generale de la Societe.Le Secretaire general, fonctionnaire charge cle mettre a execution les deci-sions de 1'Assemblee et du Conseil, dans certains cas, a agi en vertu d'instruc-tions directes de 1'Assemblee; par exemple, a propos dela convocation de laConfe-rence du transit ou de 1'envoi du questionnaire relatif a la traite des femmes et des enfants. Dans d'autres cas, il a agi en vertu destructions du Conseil, par exemple, pour reunir la Commission consultative sur le trafic de 1'opium, oupour faire les demarches necessaires en vue d'une ratification rapide du statut de la Cour permanente de justice internationale.Sans parler de la correspondance qui, a elle seule, a augmente de 130 pour cent, la tache du Secretariat, au cours de 1'annee qui .vient de s'ecouler, a ete particulierement lourde, etant donne le nombre des Commissions et conference; convoquees par la Societe. La plus grande partie des travaux preparatoires relatifs a ces Commissions et a ces conferences a ete effectuee par les soins du Secretariat, qui a egalement fourni les secretaires et le personnel necessaires.La Section juridique du Secretariat a enregistre environ 150 traites, confor-mement a 1'article 18 du Pacte. CHAPTER iii.THE WORK OF THE SECRETARIAT.The second of the reports required under Article 4 of the Rules of Procedure is described as a report " on the work of the Secretariat and upon the measures taken to execute the decisions of the Assembly. "Practically all the work of the Secretariat consists in preparing and executing the decisions of the Assembly, the Council and other organs of the League. The scope and character of these activities have already been indicated in the first two chapters of this report. It seems hardly desirable to deal with them separately, or to attempt to draw a distinction which in practice does]not exist, or exists to a very limited extent, between the activities of the Secretariat and the activities already described.It will be seen from the report that the Secretary-General, as the executive officer both of the Assembly and of the Council, has in some cases acted upon the direct instructions of the Assembly, as in convening the Transit Conference or in despatching the questionnaire concerning the traffic in women and children, and in other cases upon the instructions of the Council, as in convening the Advi-sory Committee on the Traffic in Opium, or in taking steps to procure an early ratification of the Statute of the Permanent Court of international Justice.The work of the Secretariat during the past year, apart from the current correspondence (which has increased by over 130 per cent.), has been heavy owing to the numerous committees and conferences meeting within the organisation of the League. By far the greater part of the preparatory work for these committees and conferences has been done by the Secretariat, which has also provided the necessary secretaries and the organising and clerical staff.The Legal Section of the Secretariat has registered some 150 treaties under Article 18 of the Covenant.
